Answer: First of all, I would say BIG NO to jump into or learn any new programming language or technologies for the shake of package. Trust me, it won’t help and it’s not a magic/tool to get the high package. As you are already a full stack developer and having 5 years of experience in php, nodejs, mysql so I think you are in the right direction. One language is sufficient to check you logical knowledge and OOPs skills as well.In addition to it, I would suggest you to come out of comfort zone. Start reading basics of DS and algo then apply in different product based companies with your current skill sFirst of all, I would say BIG NO to jump into or learn any new programming language or technologies for the shake of package. Trust me, it won’t help and it’s not a magic/tool to get the high package. As you are already a full stack developer and having 5 years of experience in php, nodejs, mysql so I think you are in the right direction. One language is sufficient to check you logical knowledge and OOPs skills as well.In addition to it, I would suggest you to come out of comfort zone. Start reading basics of DS and algo then apply in different product based companies with your current skill sets. Companies have high demand for the guys like you and you will get a good job of not only 10 LPA but more than that.One point I would like to mention you to keep your CV very clear and crispy. Just add the abstract of yourself and that should reflect your strong skill sets, it will help you to get a call from various good company. Rest you can talk everything in detail at the time of interview.Have confidence in you to win yourself then you’ll win anything in life. Don’t loose your interest in anything which you want by any means. All the best :-)

At this level of hard work and getting paid like that will either motivate you to go for more or just completely want you to quit the industry due to pressure (Burnout in tech is seriously very common).Or try this,KeeBy getting a take-home equivalent of 50LPA will get you to richest 1% of the country.This is too tough but not impossible.If you're a Software Engineer then just work on your skills, spend nights learning cutting edge coding, deployment, research, management skills and if you get lucky then you will be paid somewhere close to 25–30LPA in about 1–2 years of hard struggle.Trust me. At this level of hard work and getting paid like that will either motivate you to go for more or just completely want you to quit the industry due to pressure (Burnout in tech is seriously very common).Or try this,Keep earning a comfortable amount in the bracket 10–20LPA maintaining your work-life balance. Business may get you such amount of earning. That ain't easy too.It's your call. Answer: Much, much faster.The 2007 to 2013 timeframe was difficult for technology companies because capital was tight, risk tolerances were low, and consumers were spending less on innovation and focusing on daily survival.Today’s economy is completely different: the Dow Jones & Nasdaq Composite are currently at all-time highs, which means that investors are bullish & looking for technologies to push forward.More than that, it means thatMuch, much faster.The 2007 to 2013 timeframe was difficult for technology companies because capital was tight, risk tolerances were low, and consumers were spending less on innovation and focusing on daily survival.Today’s economy is completely different: the Dow Jones & Nasdaq Composite are currently at all-time highs, which means that investors are bullish & looking for technologies to push forward.More than that, it means that consumers have more money to spend on technology, and increased competitive pressure on tech companies will drive forward innovation as they seek to outpace their peers in the marketplace.I anticipate seeing huge gains in the tech industry over the next decade because of these factors, hopefully an order of magnitude more than we’ve seen over the last 10 years.

Answer: Faster.10 years ago (July 2007) the first iphone had barely been released. If you pick one up and try and use it now it’s not compelling. If you were to pickup a 1997 cell phone and compare it to a 2007 phone it would be big and ugly, it wouldn’t be a “feature” phone, but it would be sort of acceptable in it’s phone-ness.In 2007 a 42″ Plasma display weighed 90lbs, was nearly a foot thick, and offered 720P resolution, at a cost of $1100. Now that buys you a 65″ 4K TV that weighs 57 lb (with detachable base). 8x the resolution, 2.4x the size (square cm), and 63% of the weight.Self driving vehiclFaster.10 years ago (July 2007) the first iphone had barely been released. If you pick one up and try and use it now it’s not compelling. If you were to pickup a 1997 cell phone and compare it to a 2007 phone it would be big and ugly, it wouldn’t be a “feature” phone, but it would be sort of acceptable in it’s phone-ness.In 2007 a 42″ Plasma display weighed 90lbs, was nearly a foot thick, and offered 720P resolution, at a cost of $1100. Now that buys you a 65″ 4K TV that weighs 57 lb (with detachable base). 8x the resolution, 2.4x the size (square cm), and 63% of the weight.Self driving vehicles will change transportation from a good (a car that you buy) to a service (a car shows up and takes you where you want to go much cheaper than you can own a car... Uber+self driving cars).Robotics will take over manufacturing everywhereDrone delivery of goods will become standardPhotovoltaic panels will continue to fall to 60% of their current cost/watt (Swanson's Law (every doubling of photovoltaic panels reduces cost by 20%) and that Solar power will go from 1% to 32% of electrical power production in this time period)Medical devices will take over huge amounts of what we currently understand as the domain of doctors.3D printers will produce 10% or more of the goods we use on a daily basis, including some foodsWearable computing becomes viable and augmented reality becomes normal4G networks give way to 5G and 6G networks that relay data 100 x faster (500Mb/sec in places with good connectivity).Towards the end of this period household robots are available that do 90% of existing housework without incurring the maintenance of existing household robots.Home automation becomes standard (open and close drapes and curtains, music and entertainment follows you through the house, radically better smart agents allow you to always work/learn/organize)Automation will begin causing massive unemployment in this time period.

Answer: Well, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technologWell, let’s think about it for a bit.What kind of technologies have been invented in the last century?We have things like radar, and microwave, and the internet, and satellites and computer chips, and nuclear power, and canned food, and drones, and aviation technology, and GPS, and infant formula, and indexing of websites for search engines, and bar codes, and touch screens, and vaccines, and windpower, and the accelerometer, and fire resistant clothing, and aerodynamic trucks, airbags, miniature cameras that fit in a webcam or cellphone, weather forecasting, and submarines, cellular technology and networks, RAM memory, hard disk drives, liquid-crystal displays, lithium batteries, so on.But all that kind of stuff was developed by having governments getting involved, funding research and science and so on.Which, as we all know, is a really inefficient method, it pretty much doesn’t work.Instead of this inefficient method that clearly doesn’t work, of having governments take part in research and development, we now have a much better strategy for innovation:Random guys in their garage!As we all know, that’s where all the true innovation comes from, random middle class dudes, who have ideas, and then do a startup in their garage.Either that, or huge corporations who invest in ways to extend their patents.So now, we have much more groundbreaking innovation.We have things like Amazon, who patented and made a fortune off one-click buying, the truly revolutionary idea of not making people click more than needed.Do you really think that government could have ever come up with a brilliant idea like that, huh?

Answer: The creation of new technologies plays a huge part in human evolution.The creation of new technologies plays a huge part in human evolution.The creation of new technologies has a huge impact on our lives. Some of them are good but some are shaping us in directions that are increasingly harmful to us and to our society. We are coevolving with our technologies, as we did for hundreds of thousands to even millions of years, ever since we acquired fire, which shaped our digestive system because it provided us with an easier way of extracting nutrients from our food and that in turn provided us with excess energy to feed our growing brain. Or ever since the stone age, which shaped the evolution of the dexterity of our hands for creating and using stone tools or shoulders for throwing weapons made with stone tools when we were hunting.The question was: Has technology already affected human evolution?
